posts.cooked: I do not want to give signal access to my camera in order to make a group call. Why is this a requirement? The call didn’t go very well because we didn’t have the bandwidth to support video, and I don’t like the idea of giving signal access to the camera in the first place.

link_counts.title: Can't join a group call without camera permissions

posts.cooked: I’m not sure why groups don’t have an audio call button like one-on-one chats do, but you can turn your camera off before starting or joining the call, so it doesn’t make much difference aside from the permission. That will also take care of the bandwidth issue.

What you call ‘off’ and what I call ‘off’ are two different things. Anyways, moving on.
As the recipient of the call, I rejected the call because I didn’t want to enable the camera. I wasn’t allowed to answer because of this. Then when I say ‘Only this time’ (which seems to keep it on perpetually), it gives me a one time chance to tap ‘answer without video’, but it’s kind of hidden, and most users their first time aren’t going to tap on that. On my third try, I didn’t even get the option to to tap ‘answer without video’, it just defaults to video.
The people I was calling were not able to figure out how to disable video.
I don’t see why it needs to have this much complexity to not have video, and I shouldn’t have to grant this much permission. If I ever have to onboard someone new onto a platform, I am going to use SimpleX.

Herohtar:

I’m not sure why groups don’t have an audio call button like one-on-one chats do

I never noticed this. It makes sense to have group audio calls.

anon4111822:

What you call ‘off’ and what I call ‘off’ are two different things.

Off is off. There is no difference between “off with permission disabled” and “off with permission enabled”, other than what the app is allowed to do, but if you turn the camera off in the call, it is indeed off and video will not be recorded or transmitted.

anon4111822:

The people I was calling were not able to figure out how to disable video.

It literally requires a single tap on the camera icon that is continuously visible on screen while you are in the call – they couldn’t figure that out and you weren’t able to communicate that to them?

anon4111822:

As the recipient of the call, I rejected the call because I didn’t want to enable the camera. I wasn’t allowed to answer because of this. Then when I say ‘Only this time’ (which seems to keep it on perpetually), it gives me a one time chance to tap ‘answer without video’, but it’s kind of hidden, and most users their first time aren’t going to tap on that. On my third try, I didn’t even get the option to to tap ‘answer without video’, it just defaults to video.

It sounds like the UI could use some improvement in that area. You should get a consistent behavior that always presents you with the same options. It also definitely needs to be possible to answer a call with audio only without enabling the camera permission and only be prompted for camera permissions if you try to turn on the camera.

I wonder what would happen on phones that have a physical switch for the camera. If it were switched off, could that person not participate in a group call at all because Signal wouldn’t get past trying to access it?

Herohtar:

Off is off.

Right, but now I have to trust you, or go inspect the code myself and always check the code after every release instead of trusting the android permission.

Herohtar:

It literally requires a single tap on the camera icon that is continuously visible on screen while you are in the call – they couldn’t figure that out and you weren’t able to communicate that to them?

Apparently not. I didn’t have that screen to direct them as my camera was already turned off, and I couldn’t direct them because I didn’t know how. There was no button on my screen because I wasn’t in that mode.
posts.edit_reason: A post was merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked:
anon4111822:

If I ever have to onboard someone new onto a platform, I am going to use SimpleX.

Your friends couldn’t even figure out how to turn the camera on/off during a call and you are going to onboard them to SimpleX? Good luck with that

anon4111822:

I don’t see why it needs to have this much complexity to not have video

On a more serious note, I do agree that there should perhaps be an audio-only icon in the UI to just have an audio-only call from the start. I am guessing the designers went for simplicity in the sense that there is a video button, you press it and then disable video, but on this occasion they didn’t think too deeply about the fact an unnecessary permission is required.

Herohtar:

There is no difference between “off with permission disabled” and “off with permission enabled”, other than what the app is allowed to do

I think that’s the OP’s point of contention; some people trust the OS more than the app (any app). If the OS doesn’t let the app access the camera, they are more at peace than if they have to trust that the app will keep the camera off when it says it will.

anon4111822:

ight, but now I have to trust you, or go inspect the code myself and always check the code after every release instead of trusting the android permission

No you don’t. Android (at least recent versions) displays an indicator when the camera is in use so you can easily see that the camera is indeed off. Unless you don’t trust the OS to report that truthfully, in which case you can’t trust the OS to actually apply the permission either.

Herohtar:

No you don’t.

While I agree with you, if I were engaged in an audio only call, I would not be looking at the screen to verify that the camera were indeed off. If Signal has the permission to activate the camera, it could do so at any time during the call.

Herohtar:

Android (at least recent versions) displays an indicator when the camera is in use so you can easily see that the camera is indeed off

Though the line between camera/microphone on or off has been blurred for a while now. Signal changed the app to just not send audio or video data when mic muted or camera disabled, instead of actually stop engaging them. You can notice this by muting the microphone for example and observe that the Android/iOS indicator shows microphone is still open by Signal.

QuickBanana:

You can notice this by muting the microphone for example and observe that the Android/iOS indicator shows microphone is still open by Signal.

Interesting. I wonder if it’s somehow not possible to actually disable the mic for some reason? That might be worth creating a bug report about.

Another interesting thing is that Signal doesn’t enable the mic unless someone else is in the call – if you start a group call and you’re the only one there, the mic indicator doesn’t show up until someone else joins.

The camera toggle does disable the camera indicator though, no matter what the mic/call state is.

Herohtar:

I wonder if it’s somehow not possible to actually disable the mic for some reason?

That would be an OS bug.

Herohtar:

That might be worth creating a bug report about.

Has already been reported on iOS apparently: Microphone engaged even when muted · Issue #5742 · signalapp/Signal-iOS · GitHub

link_counts.title: Microphone engaged even when muted · Issue #5742 · signalapp/Signal-iOS · GitHub

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
anon4111822:

I do not want to give signal access to my camera in order to make a group call. Why is this a requirement? The call didn’t go very well because we didn’t have the bandwidth to support video, and I don’t like the idea of giving signal access to the camera in the first place.

I am having this exact same issue on iOS. I also give my apps only the bare minimum permissions, but Signal seems to be the only calling/messaging app that does not allow me to join group calls without the camera permission.

Herohtar:
anon4111822:

ight, but now I have to trust you, or go inspect the code myself and always check the code after every release instead of trusting the android permission

No you don’t. Android (at least recent versions) displays an indicator when the camera is in use so you can easily see that the camera is indeed off. Unless you don’t trust the OS to report that truthfully, in which case you can’t trust the OS to actually apply the permission either.

I have a somewhat unique but similar issue with giving my camera permission. I trust Signal not to spy on me obviously, but I don’t trust myself to always remember to disable the video. I do video calls sometimes, but once I’m done I always turn the permission back off to ensure I can never accidentally join a video call.

I think adding a voice call button would solve the issue perfectly. However, if the Signal developers don’t want to change the UI, then allowing us to join a group call without camera permissions would be enough to satisfy me.

Signal’s UX around permissions is generally pretty bad, and it’s sad to see it’s still not good in 2025. Group calls, stories, and now call links, can’t be used without camera permissions.

Apps should work around users not granting them permissions, and users shouldn’t be forced to grant permissions to use functionality that doesn’t strictly require them.

Plenty of people join calls without using video, and some even without microphone. Signal calls and stories should work in any case.

Moreover, Signal doesn’t even have good UX when permission is granted. For example, I can’t remove people on my contacts list from the Signal contacts list. What if I don’t want to talk to that person on Signal? Signal fails very badly in this case, and it’ll just lead me to revoking contacts permission from Signal.
